Literature Review: The exploration of RNA modifications has unveiled a complex layer of post-transcriptional regulation that plays a pivotal role in gene expression. Initially identified in tRNAs and rRNAs, RNA modifications have since been discovered across a wide range of RNA species, including mRNA, in various organisms, including plants. This literature review focuses on the diversity and functions of RNA modifications in plants, highlighting recent advancements and future directions in this burgeoning field. RNA modifications, such as N6-methyladenosine (m6A) and 5-methylcytosine (m5C), have been shown to influence RNA stability, translation, and transport, thereby affecting plant development and stress responses. The chemical nature of these modifications, along with the enzymes responsible for their addition (writers), recognition (readers), and removal (erasers), has been a subject of intense study. Recent research has demonstrated that m6A, the most prevalent mRNA modification in eukaryotes, plays a crucial role in plant stress responses. For instance, studies have shown that m6A modifications can enhance the stability of stress-responsive mRNAs, thereby facilitating plant adaptation to adverse environmental conditions. Similarly, m5C modifications in tRNAs have been implicated in the regulation of translation efficiency and fidelity under stress conditions. Beyond these well-characterized modifications, the plant transcriptome harbors a plethora of other RNA modifications whose functions remain to be fully elucidated. The advent of high-throughput sequencing technologies and advanced mass spectrometry techniques has significantly accelerated the discovery and functional characterization of RNA modifications in plants. These technological advancements have enabled researchers to map RNA modifications at a genome-wide scale and to investigate their dynamic changes in response to developmental cues and environmental stimuli. Despite these progresses, several key questions remain unanswered. For example, the specific roles of many RNA modifications in plant gene expression and their interplay with other regulatory mechanisms are still poorly understood. Moreover, the impact of RNA modifications on the spatial and temporal regulation of gene expression in plants warrants further investigation. Future research should also aim to elucidate the evolutionary conservation and divergence of RNA modification pathways across different plant species. In conclusion, the study of RNA modifications in plants has opened up new avenues for understanding the complexity of gene regulation. As we continue to uncover the diversity and functions of RNA modifications, it is imperative to integrate these findings with other aspects of plant biology to gain a holistic view of plant gene expression and its regulation.
